block.p: Iran Agrees to Cooperate On Nuclear Restrictions Iran agreed, during an unusual visit to Tehran by three European foreign ministers, to accept stricter international inspections of its nuclear facilities and to suspend production of enriched uranium.

Pearl Case Tied to Al Qaeda American officials said that Khalid Sheik Mohammed, once Al Qaeda's top operational commander, personally executed Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal reporter who was abducted in Pakistan last year.

Asians Add Security to Agenda President Bush persuaded Asia's largest economic group, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, to crack down on terrorism and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
More Troops May Go to Iraq Senior Pentagon officials said that more National Guard and Reserve forces would be notified in coming weeks that they may have to serve in Iraq next year.
American troops helping the Iraqi police during a raid on a mosque in Karbala arrested 32 supporters of Sheik Moktada al-Sadr, a fundamentalist Shiite cleric who has openly defied the United States.

Speculation in Rome Pope John Paul II gave signature red hats to 30 new Roman Catholic Cardinals, capping a series of events in Rome that offered clues and fueled speculation about the future of the church.
Powell Pushes Sudan Peace Secretary of State Colin L. Powell suggested that the United States would lift sanctions on Sudan if the country reached a peace accord and acted further against terrorism.

Arab Rage; Israeli Videotape Israelis and Palestinians presented opposing, vivid versions of an airstrike that killed seven Palestinians and wounded many others. Criticism from within Israel prompted the air force to show reporters video footage of the strike.

Senate Approves Ban On an Abortion Procedure The Senate overwhelmingly approved the first federal ban on a specific abortion procedure, ending eight years of divisive debate and clearing the way for President Bush to sign the measure into law.

Sniper Defendant as Lawyer The courtroom skills of John A. Muhammad, on trial in the Washington area sniper killings, were put to the test a day after he fired his lawyers. His courtroom demeanor was fine, but he stumbled on legal issues, as experts had predicted.

Feeding Ordered in Florida Six days after the feeding tube of a brain-damaged woman was removed, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida ordered it reinserted after the Legislature empowered him to do so, overriding years of court rulings.

Census of Mentally Ill Inmates As many as one in five of the 2.1 million Americans in jail and prison are mentally ill, far outnumbering those who are in mental hospitals, a comprehensive study found.
AWOL After a Break From Iraq Pentagon officials disclosed that 28 soldiers who had been granted a 15-day leave from the war in Iraq as part of an experimental program have not reported back to duty.

Permanent U.S. Prison in Cuba The Guant√°namo Bay detention facility is taking on a permanent air as the authorities build a hard-walled traditional prison alongside the units that have housed detainees for nearly two years.

Academy Rethinks Ban The chief lobbyist for the movie industry is expected to reverse an edict barring studios from sending videos of their films to Academy Award voters, industry executives involved in the discussions said.

Report Finds Neglect Of Mentally Ill in Prison A report released by the Correctional Association of New York shows that nearly one of every four New York State prisoners who are kept in punitive segregation is mentally ill, and the state Department of Correctional Services rarely does anything to help them.

Niagara Stunt Was Planned The man who intentionally went over Niagara Falls without a barrel told his family of his plan in advance. He will be charged with mischief and performing an unlawful stunt within a government-run park.

Husband Sues Liza Minnelli David Gest is suing Liza Minnelli, claiming that while they lived together she went into alcohol-induced rages and beat him so badly that he ''suffers from virtually constant, unrelenting pain'' in his head.
Yankees Take Series Lead The New York Yankees defeated the Florida Marlins 6-1 to take the lead in the World Series, 2-1.
Sharp Rise in Math Scores For the first time since 1999 more than half of eighth graders in New York met math standards.

College Tuition Up Sharply The nation's public universities raised tuition by 14 percent this year according to a survey by the College Board. Tuition at community colleges across the country also rose 14 percent.

Case and Parsons Subpoenaed Stephen M. Case, former chairman of Time Warner, and Richard D. Parsons, the current chairman, have been subpoenaed in an investigation into the company's accounting for an advertising deal.

China's Greenhouse Gas China's rapid economic growth is producing a surge in emissions of greenhouse gases that threatens international efforts to curb global warming. Coal use has been climbing faster in China than practically anywhere else in the world.
